GUI

Class GUI

  • java.lang.Object
    • java.awt.Component
      • java.awt.Container
        • java.awt.Window
          • java.awt.Frame
            • javax.swing.JFrame
              • GUI.GUI
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    java.awt.event.ActionListener, java.awt.image.ImageObserver, java.awt.MenuContainer, java.io.Serializable, java.lang.Runnable, java.util.EventListener, javax.accessibility.Accessible, javax.swing.RootPaneContainer, javax.swing.WindowConstants

    public class GUI
extends javax.swing.JFrame
implements java.awt.event.ActionListener, java.lang.Runnable
    This class displays and handles the functions of the main graphical user interface, where the majority of the user tasks are completed. It extends the JFrame and implements ActionListener and Runnable.
    Author:
    Brant Geeves
    See Also:
    Serialized Form

    • Constructor Detail

      • GUI

        public GUI()
    throws java.awt.HeadlessException
        Constructor for a new GUI and passes a program name string to the super type.
        Throws:
        java.awt.HeadlessException - - throws this exception if the system is put into headless mode

    • Method Detail

      • createGUI

        private void createGUI()
                throws java.io.IOException,
                       StockException
        This class is where the components of the GUI are initialised and laid out.
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException - - throws this exception when a problem is detected with IO
        StockException - - throws this exception when there is no inventory to display

      • refreshGUI

        private void refreshGUI()
                 throws StockException
        This method refreshes the dynamic elements of the GUI. It is called when a change to either the inventory or store capital has been made.
        Throws:
        StockException - - throws this exception when there is no inventory to display

      • createPanel

        private javax.swing.JPanel createPanel(java.awt.Color c)
        Creates and individual JPanel object and sets its background colour. The JPaenls are used to hold the other components of the GUI like buttons.
        Parameters:
        c - - the panels colour
        Returns:
        jp - the panel object

      • createButton

        private javax.swing.JButton createButton(java.lang.String str)
        Creates an individual JButton and adds and action listener to it, in order to know when a button has been clicked by the user.
        Parameters:
        str - - a string representing the buttons label
        Returns:
        jb - the button object

      • createTableArea

        private javax.swing.JScrollPane createTableArea()
        Creates a JScrollPane object that is used to hold the inventory table. A scroll pane is necessary so that the table can be scrolled if the size grows too large for the window.
        Returns:
        scrl - the scroll pane object

      • layoutHeaderPanel

        private void layoutHeaderPanel()
        This method initialises and lays out the components in the header panel of the GUI. This is where the store name and capital are displayed.

      • checkCapital

        private void checkCapital()
        Checks the value of the store capital. If it is positive, the capital is displayed in green. If it is negative, the capital is displayed red.

      • layoutButtonPanel

        private void layoutButtonPanel()

      • addToPanel

        private void addToPanel(javax.swing.JPanel jp,
                        java.awt.Component c,
                        java.awt.GridBagConstraints constraints,
                        int x,
                        int y,
                        int w,
                        int h)
        A convenience method to add a component to given grid bag layout locations. Code due to Cay Horstmann
        Parameters:
        c - the component to add
        jp - the JPanel object
        constraints - the grid bag constraints to use
        x - the x grid position
        y - the y grid position
        w - the grid width
        h - the grid height

      • run

        public void run()
        Over-rides the run function from Runnable.
        Specified by:
        run in interface java.lang.Runnable

        Runnable.run()

      • actionPerformed

        public void actionPerformed(java.awt.event.ActionEvent e)
        Over-rides the actionPerformed function from ActionListener. This is where the program is notified of a button click by the user and performs the appropriate function. If an exception is thrown from one of the back-end processes, this is where the exception is caught and a message is displayed to the user about the issue. *
        Specified by:
        actionPerformed in interface java.awt.event.ActionListener
        See Also:
        ActionListener.actionPerformed(java.awt.event.ActionEvent)
